body.p: In the Preferences pages each particular setting (configurable via UI controls like radio buttons, check boxes, option boxes) has a default value. This default value is used by the application as long as the user does not explicitly change that setting to some other value. You can overwrite these default values/settings for a specific installation by loading a set of options from a specific XML structure stored in an options file.

section.title: Creating an XML options file
Providing Default Option Values
section.p: Use either one of the following ways to configure an installation to use customized default options from an XML configuration file:

li.p: set the path to the XML options configuration file as the value of the com.oxygenxml.default.options system propertysystem property.
The path must be specified with an URL or a file path relative to the application installation folder:-Dcom.oxygenxml.default.options=options/default.xml
You can add the following line in the [Eclipse-platform-install-folder]/configuration/config.ini file:com.oxygenxml.default.options=file\:@config.dir/../default-options.xml
li.note: If you are using the Java Webstart distribution, edit the .jnlp file that launches the application and set the com.oxygenxml.default.options parameter using a property element, for example: <property name="oxy:com.oxygenxml.default.options" value="http://host/path/to/default-options.xml"/>

ul.li: copy the XML options configuration file to the [Oxygen-install-folder]/preferences[Eclipse-platform-install-folder]/plugins/com.oxygenxml.editor/preferences folder or to the equivalent plugin folder in the [Eclipse-platform-install-folder]/dropins folder if the plugin was installed as a drop-in..The same procedure applies to a Java Webstart distribution.

section.note: Make sure that the options configuration file has either the .xml extension (eg: default-options.xml) or an .xpr extension depending on the way in which it was created (from the global options or saved at project level).
Make sure that the options configuration file has the .xml extension (eg: default-options.xml).
